fields.value: Medical Education, Digital Health
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Country
fields.description: Country or countries where the study was conducted or primarily situated
fields.value: Germany
fields.evidence_quote: "The “Digital Health” curriculum was introduced at a German university"

fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.
fields.value: Original Research
fields.evidence_quote: "This prospective pilot study was designed as a pre-post analysis to assess the development in subjective competence and the subjectively perceived impact of our digital health curriculum on the perception about the relevance of digital health topics for future professional challenges."

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To evaluate the impact of a digital health curriculum on medical students' perceptions of the relevance and competence in digital health topics, and to analyze the acceptance of gamification-based teaching methods.
fields.evidence_quote: "The study aims: (1) to analyze the impact of a transdisciplinary digital health curriculum on students’ perceived relevance and competence regarding digital health topics and (2) to analyze the acceptance and suitability of a gamification-based teaching method integrated into the existing curriculum."

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: The digital health curriculum improved students' perceived competence in most topics, with robotics showing the greatest increase. Students found gamification-based teaching enjoyable and suitable for reducing reservations about robotics.
fields.evidence_quote: "Significant increases in perceived importance were observed for messenger apps... Regarding self-assessed competence, significant development was observed on almost all topics. The greatest development was observed in robotics... The gamification-based, robot-related teaching was predominantly rated suitable and very enjoyable for the students."

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any meaningful or intentional involvement of patients or the public in any phase of the research or implementation?
fields.value: No
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Type of Engagement (Montreal Model continuum)
fields.description: Categorize engagement based on the Montreal Model: Information (e.g., newsletters), Consultation (e.g., surveys, focus groups), Collaboration (e.g., co-design sessions), or Partnership (e.g., decision-making roles, advisory boards).
fields.value: Consultation - Student feedback was gathered through pre- and post-curriculum surveys and a follow-up evaluation.
fields.evidence_quote: "Furthermore, the practical gamification-based teaching part of the robotics teaching unit was evaluated. In total, 6 months after completing the last semester, a follow-up analysis was performed with questions on the significance of the completed curriculum for current and future professional challenges regarding digital health and suggestions for improvement for innovative teaching."

fields.name: Level of Patient Involvement (Montreal Model)
fields.description: At what level were patients or the public involved across the research lifecycle? Score each phase (design, development, evaluation, implementation) as: None, Information, Consultation, Collaboration, or Partnership.
fields.value: Design: None, Development: None, Evaluation: Consultation, Implementation: None
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Evaluation of Impact (Y/N)
fields.description: Did the study evaluate or measure the effect of patient/public engagement?
fields.value: Yes
fields.evidence_quote: "This study aimed to evaluate the impact of the “Digital Health” curriculum at our university on the perceptions of medical students regarding the relevance of digital health topics for their future professions and their self-assessed competence in these areas."

fields.name: Type of Evaluation
fields.description: What type of method or framework was used to evaluate the impact of engagement (e.g., metrics, qualitative feedback, evaluation framework)?
fields.value: Pre-post comparison using Likert scales and retrospective online survey.
fields.evidence_quote: "This prospective pilot study was designed as a pre-post analysis to assess the development in subjective competence and the subjectively perceived impact of our digital health curriculum on the perception about the relevance of digital health topics for future professional challenges."

fields.name: Impact of Engagement
fields.description: Describe any outcomes or changes attributed to patient/public engagement (e.g., design changes, improved recruitment, insights).
fields.value: Identified areas for curriculum improvement, including adapting teaching methods and incorporating existing apps for digital documentation.
fields.evidence_quote: "In follow-up question 5, former participants were asked to provide their assessment of the extent to which teaching should be adapted to the challenges of digital transformation. In particular an adaptation of the learning methodology (n=6); especially AI-supported, for more individualized or efficient or sustainable learning), familiarization with existing apps (n=5); especially digital documentation systems) and the general inclusion of digital health subjects (n=4) was indicated."

fields.name: Participatory Process
fields.description: Did the study include a participatory design process such as workshops, co-design, or stakeholder sessions?
fields.value: No
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Continuous Evaluation Cycles
fields.description: Was engagement conducted iteratively or cyclically, with feedback loops or repeated interaction?
fields.value: Yes - Follow-up evaluation was conducted 6 months and 1 year after the curriculum.
fields.evidence_quote: "In total, 6 months (cohort 1) and 1 year (cohort 2) after completion of the curriculum, participants were asked to participate in a retrospective online survey using the online tool SurveyMonkey"

fields.name: Implementation
fields.description: Did patient/public engagement influence the implementation strategy or process of the research?
fields.value: Yes - Feedback informed future curriculum design and teaching methods.
fields.evidence_quote: "Taking the follow-up analysis into account, we feel that we will offer the compulsory elective subject in the future. However, the focus will be on further adaptation of teaching methods (digital transformation of medical education) as well as the increased teaching of existing apps for digital documentation systems."

fields.name: Organization of Health Care
fields.description: Did engagement lead to reported changes in health care delivery, systems design, or institutional practice?
fields.value: No
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Persuasive Design Techniques
fields.description: Were behavior-change strategies or persuasive technologies mentioned (e.g., nudges, gamification, reminders)?
fields.value: Yes - Gamification was used in the robotics teaching unit.
fields.evidence_quote: "A promising approach is gamification, which refers to the integration of playful elements in a serious context. Educators in the health care sector are also increasingly relying on gamification to optimize students’ learning success"

fields.name: Assess Impact
fields.description: Did the study measure outcomes or success metrics related specifically to engagement efforts?
fields.value: Yes - The study assessed the impact of the curriculum and gamification on student perceptions and competence.
fields.evidence_quote: "This study provides an overview of the influence of our digital health curriculum on students’ perception about their competence and the relevance of digital health topics for their future professional challenges."

fields.name: Information
fields.description: Was information provided to patients/public about the study, without involving them in decision-making?
fields.value: Yes - Students were informed about the curriculum and its social media channel.
fields.evidence_quote: "At the beginning of the curriculum, all participants were informed of the existence of a social media channel."

fields.evidence_quote: "In total, 6 months (cohort 1) and 1 year (cohort 2) after completion of the curriculum, participants were asked to participate in a retrospective online survey using the online tool SurveyMonkey"
